revision.text:
{{About|veneration of [[Mary, mother of Jesus]], in the [[Catholic Church]]|Catholic Marian doctrines|Roman Catholic Mariology}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2014}} <!-- PLEASE ADD ANY ADDITIONAL FEAST DAYS, TITLES OR SHRINES TO THE APPROPRIATE "MAIN PAGE". AFTER A LONG DISCUSSION ON THE TALK PAGE IT WAS DECIDED THAT THE LISTS HERE WILL BE KEPT TO "6 OR 7 ITEMS AT MOST" AND ADDITIONAL ITEMS WILL HAVE TO BE ADDED TO THEIR "MAIN PAGE". THESE LISTS WILL BE TRIMMED IF NEW ITEMS APPEAR ON THEM. THANK YOU. --> <!-- This article was the subject of a merge proposal Talk:Mary_(mother_of_Jesus)#Merge_proposal and the conclusion was not to merge, but keep it. --> {{Infobox saint | name = Blessed Virgin Mary | feast_day = See [[Marian feast days]] | venerated_in = [[Catholic Church]] | image = 1460 Osservanza Master Madonna and Child anagoria.JPG | caption = "The Church's devotion to the Blessed Virgin is intrinsic to Christian worship."<ref name="ccc971">{{CCC|971}}</ref> | birth_date = September 8 ([[Nativity of Mary]]) | birth_place = | death_date = August 15 ([[Assumption of Mary]]) | death_place = | titles = [[Mother of God (Roman Catholic)|Mother of God]], [[Queen of Heaven]], [[Mother of the Church]], [[Mediatrix]], [[Co-Redemptrix]], [[Titles of Mary|Our Lady]] | canonized_date = [[Congregation for the Causes of Saints|Pre-Congregation]] | attributes = Blue mantle, white veil, Immaculate heart, crown of 12 stars, pregnant woman, halo with 12 stars, roses, woman with child | patronage = See [[Patronage of the Blessed Virgin Mary]] | major_shrine = [[Santa Maria Maggiore]], others (see [[Shrines to the Virgin Mary]]) }} In the [[Catholic Church]], the veneration of [[Mary, mother of Jesus]], encompasses various [[Marian devotion]]s which include prayer, pious acts, visual arts, poetry, and music devoted to the Blessed Virgin Mary.<ref>{{Cite magazine|date=27 March 1927|title=Santa Maria|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,730158-1,00.html|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|doi=|pmid=|access-date=6 June 2016|registration=yes}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UFFJb3uNxdUC&pg=PA151|title=Symbolic Scores: Studies in the Music of the Renaissance|last=Elders|first=Willem|publisher=E.J. Brill|year=1994|isbn=978-9004099708|edition=Illustrated|series=Symbola et emblemata: studies in Renaissance and baroque symbolism|volume=5|location=Leiden, Netherlands|pages=151|issn=0923-9073}}</ref> Popes have encouraged it, while also taking steps to reform some manifestations of it.<ref group="note">For example, on March 12, 1969, [[Pope Paul VI]] reduced and rearranged the number of Marian feast days in ''Sanctitas clarior''. Several of his predecessors did similarly.</ref> The [[Holy See]] has insisted on the importance of distinguishing "true from false devotion, and authentic doctrine from its deformations by excess or defect".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/ccatheduc/documents/rc_con_ccatheduc_doc_19880325_vergine-maria_sp.html|title=La Virgen María en la formación intelectual y espiritual|last=William|first=Baum|date=25 March 1988|website=The Holy See|publisher=[[Congregation for Catholic Education]]|location=Rome|language=Spanish|trans-title=The Virgin Mary in the Intellectual and Spiritual Formation|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> There are significantly more titles, feasts, and venerative Marian practices among Roman Catholics than in other Western Christian traditions.<ref name="FrankFlinn">{{Cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=Mary of Nazareth|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Catholicism|publisher=[[Infobase Publishing]]|location=New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gxEONS0FFlsC|accessdate=6 June 2016|last=Flinn|first=Frank K.|date=|editor-last=Melton|editor-first=J. Gordon|series=Encyclopedia of World Religions|pages=441–448|isbn=9780816075652}}</ref> The term ''[[hyperdulia]]'' indicates the special veneration due to Mary, greater than the ordinary ''[[dulia]]'' for other saints, but utterly unlike the ''[[latria]]'' due only to God. The term "[[Mariolatry]]" is a [[Protestant]] pejorative label for perceived excessive Catholic devotion to Mary.
Belief in the [[Incarnation (Christianity)|incarnation]] of [[God the Son]] through Mary is the basis for calling her the [[Mother of God (Roman Catholic)|Mother of God]], which was declared a dogma at the [[First Council of Ephesus|Council of Ephesus]] in 431. At the [[Second Vatican Council]] and in [[Pope John Paul II]]'s encyclical ''[[Redemptoris Mater|Redemptoris mater]]'', she is spoken of also as Mother of the Church.<ref name="RedMater" />
Growth of Roman Catholic veneration of Mary and [[Mariology (Roman Catholic)|Mariology]] has often come not from official declarations, but from [[Mariology of the saints|Marian writings of the saints]], popular devotion, and at times reported [[Marian apparitions]]. The [[Holy See]] approves only a select few as worthy of belief; most recently the 2008 recognition of apparitions as far back as 1665.<ref name="catholicnewsagency1">{{cite news|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/vatican_recognizes_marian_apparitions_in_france/|title=Vatican recognizes Marian apparitions in France|date=5 May 2008|work=[[Catholic News Agency]]|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref><ref name="catholicnewsagency2">{{cite news|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/expert_explains_churchs_criteria_for_confirming_marian_apparitions/|title=Expert explains Church’s criteria for confirming Marian apparitions.|last=Perrella|first=Salvatore M.|date=8 May 2008|work=[[Catholic News Agency]]|publisher=|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
Further pious veneration of the Blessed Virgin Mary encouraged by [[Pope]]s are exhibited in the [[canonical coronation]]s granted to popular Marian images venerated in a particular locality all over the world, while [[Marian movements and societies]] with millions of members have arisen from belief in events such as [[Our Lady of Akita|Akita]], [[Our Lady of Fatima|Fátima]], and [[Our Lady of Lourdes|Lourdes]], and other reasons.<ref name="udayton1">{{cite web|url=https://udayton.edu/imri/mary/index.php|title=Pastoral Marian Organizations in the United States|last=Hogan|first=Robert|last2=Kulkarni|first2=Sumithra|date=7 February 2012|website=International Marian Research Institute|publisher=The Marian Library/International Marian Research Institute|orig-year=1995|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
==From Christ to Mary in the Roman Catholic tradition== {{Roman Catholic Mariology}}
In Roman Catholic teachings, the veneration of Mary is a natural consequence of [[Christology]]: Jesus and Mary are son and mother, redeemer and redeemed.<ref name="Rahner903">{{Cite encyclopedia|year=2004|title=Mariology|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia of Theology: A Concise Sacramentum Mundi|publisher=St Pauls|location=Mumbai|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WtnR-6_PlJAC|accessdate=6 June 2016|last=Schmaus|first=Michael|date=|origyear=1975|editor-last=Rahner|editor-first=Karl|pages=893–905|isbn=9780860120063}}</ref> This sentiment was expressed by [[Pope John Paul II]] in his encyclical ''Redemptoris mater'': "At the centre of this mystery, in the midst of this wonderment of faith, stands Mary. As the loving Mother of the Redeemer, she was the first to experience it: 'To the wonderment of nature you bore your Creator'!"<ref name="RedMater">{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/encyclicals/documents/hf_jp-ii_enc_25031987_redemptoris-mater_en.html|title=''Redemptoris mater''|date=25 March 1987|location=Rome|work=The Holy See|accessdate=6 June 2016|author=Pope John Paul II}}</ref>
In the Roman Catholic tradition Mariology is seen as Christology developed to its full potential.<ref>See [[Pope Pius XII]], ''[[Mystici corporis Christi]]''; [[John Henry Cardinal Newman]]: ''Mariology is always christocentric'', in Michael Testa, ''Mary: The Virgin Mary in the Life and Writings of John Henry Newman'' (2001); and ''Mariology Is Christology'' in [[Vittorio Messori]], "The Mary Hypothesis" (Rome, 2005).</ref> Mary is seen as contributing to a fuller understanding of the life of Jesus. In this view, a Christology without Mary is not based on the total revelation of the Bible. Traces of this parallel interpretation go back to the early days of Christianity and numerous saints have since focused on it.<ref name=Rahner903 />
The development of this approach continued into the 20th century. In his 1946 publication ''Compendium Mariologiae'', [[Mariology(RC)|Mariologist]] [[Gabriel Roschini]] explained that Mary not only participated in the birth of the physical Jesus, but, with conception, she entered with him into a [[Spirituality|spiritual]] union. The divine salvation plan, being not only material, includes a permanent spiritual unity with Christ.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Mary for Evangelicals: Toward an Understanding of the Mother of Our Lord|last=Perry|first=Tim|last2=Abraham|first2=William J.|publisher=InterVarsity Press|year=2006|isbn=9780830825691|edition=Illustrated|location=Downers Grove, Illinois|pages=303}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t_JtmrGDLB4C|title=Mary's Pope: John Paul II, Mary, and the Church Since Vatican II|last=Nachef|first=Antoine|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=2000|isbn=9781580510776|location=Franklin, Wisconsin|pages=9|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0L_WmgEACAAJ|title=Mariologie|last=Schmaus|first=Michael|publisher=Hueber|year=1955|isbn=|series=''Katholische Dogmatik'' [''Catholic Dogma'']|volume=5|location=|pages=328|trans-title=Mariology|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref> Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger (later [[Pope Benedict XVI]]) wrote: "It is necessary to go back to Mary if we want to return to that 'truth about Jesus Christ,' 'truth about the Church' and 'truth about man' that [[Pope John Paul II|John Paul II]] proposed as a program to all of Christianity," in order to ensure an authentic approach to Christology via a return to the "whole truth about Mary".<ref name="BurkeMariology">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ez0VRbQi1i4C|title=Mariology: A Guide for Priests, Deacons, Seminarians and Consecrated Persons|publisher=Seat of Wisdom Books|year=2007|isbn=9781579183554|editor-last=Miravalle|editor-first=Mark I.|location=Goleta, Georgia|pages=xxi–xxiii|chapter=Editor's Introduction|access-date=6 June 2016}}</ref>
==From veneration to theology== It is possible that the practice of invoking the aid of the Mother of Christ had become more familiar to the faithful some time before any expression of it in the writings of the [[Early Church Fathers]].<ref name="Thurston">{{Cite encyclopedia|title=Devotion to the Blessed Virgin Mary|encyclopedia=The Catholic Encyclopedia|publisher=Robert Appleton Company|location=New York|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/15459a.htm|accessdate=6 June 2016|last=Thurston|first=Herbert|date=1912|volume=15}}</ref> Christians' love for Mary intuited, frequently in anticipation, certain aspects of the mystery of the Blessed Virgin, calling the attention of theologians and pastors to them.<ref name="gaudience">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ewtn.com/library/papaldoc/jp2bvm4.htm|title=Church Grew in Understanding of Mary's Role|last=Pope John Paul II|date=15 November 1995|publisher=The Cathedral Foundation|newspaper=[[L'Osservatore Romano]]|page=11|access-date=6 June 2016|via=[[EWTN]]}}</ref> Venerative and devotional practices have often preceded formal theological declarations by the [[Magisterium]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DWdk0AZlzZIC|title=The Liturgy and Time|last=Martimort|first=Aimé Georges|last2=Dalmais|first2=Irénée Henri|last3=Jounel|first3=Pierre|publisher=The Liturgical Press|others=Translated by Matthew J. O'Connell|year=1986|isbn=9780814613665|editor-last=Martimort|editor-first=Aimé Georges|edition=New|series=''The Church at Prayer: An Introduction to the Liturgy''|volume=IV|location=Collegeville, Minnesota|pages=130|access-date=6 June 2016|display-editors=etal}}</ref><!-- Continue ref cleanup after here. -->
The veneration of the Blessed Virgin takes place in various ways. Marian prayers and hymns usually begin with praise of her, followed by petitions.<ref name=MMiles /> The number of Marian titles continued to grow as of the 3rd century, and many titles existed by the 5th century, growing especially during the Middle Ages.<ref>''Encyclopedia of the Middle Ages, Volume 2'' by André Vauchez et al 2001 {{ISBN|1-57958-282-6}} page 919</ref>
===Theological basis for the veneration of Mary=== Veneration for Mary is based on the reference in the Gospel of Luke to Mary as the selected handmaid of the Lord who is greeted and praised by both [[Elizabeth (biblical figure)|Elizabeth]] and the angel [[Gabriel]]. God's work is further illuminated in the Marian dogmas of the Roman Catholic Church such as the [[Immaculate Conception]] and the [[Assumption of Mary|Assumption]], and are, in the Roman Catholic view, part of the apostolic tradition and divine revelation.<ref name= McNally132>McNally, Terrence, ''What Every Catholic Should Know about Mary'' {{ISBN|1-4415-1051-6}} p. 132</ref><ref>Bäumer, 597</ref> Catholics distinguish veneration from worship.
===Mary's role in salvation and redemption=== [[File:Retable de l'Agneau mystique (3).jpg|thumb|left|180px|The Virgin Mary from the [[Ghent Altarpiece]], 1432]]
One of the components of the Catholic veneration of Mary is the focus on her participation in the processes of salvation and redemption.<ref>Haffner, Paul. ''The mystery of Mary'', 2004 {{ISBN|0-85244-650-0}} p. 198</ref> This has been explored by such writers as [[Edward Schillebeeckx]] and [[Adrienne von Speyr]].<ref>Schillebeeckx, Edward. ''Mary, mother of the redemption'', 1964, ASIN B003KW30VG pp. 82–84</ref><ref>Von Speyr, Adrienne, ''Mary in the Redemption'', 2003 {{ISBN|0-89870-955-5}} pp. 2–7</ref>
John's Gospel records her presence at the beginning and end of his public life. Particularly significant is Mary's presence at the Cross, when she received from her dying Son the charge to be mother to the beloved disciple and, in him, to all Christians.<ref name=gaudience/> The Acts of the Apostles expressly numbers the Mother of Jesus among the women of the first community awaiting Pentecost. [[John Eudes]] wrote that: "The Virgin Mary began to cooperate in the plan of salvation, from the moment she gave her consent to the Incarnation of the Son of God".<ref name=Aumann>''Spiritual Theology'' by Jordan Aumann 1980 {{ISBN|0-7220-8518-4}} pp. 62–67</ref>
''[[Lumen gentium]]'', the 1964 Dogmatic Constitution of the Church recognized, "...all the salvific influence of the Blessed Virgin on men originates, not from some inner necessity, but from the divine pleasure. It flows forth from the superabundance of the merits of Christ, rests on His mediation, depends entirely on it and draws all its power from it."<ref name=ppvi>[http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19641121_lumen-gentium_en.html Pope Paul VI. ''Lumen gentium'', §60, 21 November 1964]</ref> In a singular way she cooperated by her obedience, faith, hope, and burning charity in the work of the Savior in giving back supernatural life to souls. "Wherefore she is our mother in the order of grace."{{sfn|''Lumen gentium'', §61}}
One of the first scholars to offer theological foundations on the subject of the [[Immaculate Conception]] was the Franciscan [[Duns Scotus]] who developed the concept that Mary was preserved from sin by the redemptive virtue of Jesus.<ref>''Summa Theologiae: Volume 51, Our Lady: 3a. 27–30'' by Thomas Aquinas, Thomas R. Heath 2006 {{ISBN|0-521-02959-7}} page 114</ref><ref>''Encyclopedia of theology: a concise Sacramentum mundi'' by Karl Rahner 2004 {{ISBN|0-86012-006-6}} pages 896–898 [https://books.google.com/books?id=WtnR-6_PlJAC&pg=PA897&dq=mary+redemption&hl=en&ei=6gSdTIyGLsiVswab37DmDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAjge#v=onepage&q=mary%20redemption&f=false]</ref><ref>''The encyclopedia of Christianity, Volume 3'' by Erwin Fahlbusch, Geoffrey William Bromiley 2003 {{ISBN|90-04-12654-6}} page 407 [https://books.google.com/books?id=7ly4DgtT3LkC&pg=PA407&dq=mary+redemption&hl=en&ei=MAOdTO_KNs3Lswb1pbTmDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CE4Q6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=mary%20redemption&f=false]</ref> Devotions to and the veneration of the Virgin Mary continued to spread, as she came to be seen as the helpful mother of Christians, and by the 15th century these practices had oriented many Catholic devotions.<ref>''Encyclopedia of the Middle Ages, Volume 2'' by André Vauchez, Richard Barrie Dobson, Adrian Walford, Michael Lapidge 2001 {{ISBN|1-57958-282-6}} page 919</ref>
Saint [[Veronica Giuliani]] expressed how Mary's suffering in Calvary united her heart with that of Jesus as she suffered each torment along with him.<ref>''Mariology: A Guide for Priests, Deacons, Seminarians, and Consecrated Persons'' by Raymond Burke et al. 2008 {{ISBN|978-1-57918-355-4}} pages 372–373</ref> The joint devotion to the hearts was formalized by Jean Eudes who organized the scriptural and theological foundations and developed its liturgical themes.<ref>Arthur Calkins, ''The Theology of the Alliance of the Two Hearts'', [[Missio Immaculatae]] (English Edition) Year III, N° 4 (May to December 2007)</ref> The venerative aspects of the united nature of the two hearts continued through the centuries and in 1985 Pope [[John Paul II]] coined the term ''[[Alliance of the Hearts of Jesus and Mary]]'', and in 1986 addressed the international conference on that topic held at [[Fátima, Portugal]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/speeches/1986/september/documents/hf_jp-ii_spe_19860922_simposio-maria-gesu_en.html | publisher = Vatican | accessdate = October 4, 2010 | title = Address of his Holiness John Paul II to the Participants of the Study Week of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences|author=Pope John Paul II}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/angelus/1985/documents/hf_jp-ii_ang_19850915_it.html|title=Angelus, 15 settembre 1985 - Giovanni Paolo II|publisher=}}</ref><ref>''Proceedings of the International Theological Symposium on the Alliance of the Hearts of Jesus and Mary'', September 1986, Fatima, Portugal</ref>
By the 18th century, the continued growth of Marian veneration had emphasized the role of the Virgin Mary in salvation. The Catholic focus on the role of Mary in salvation and redemption continued with [[Pope John Paul II]]'s 1987 encyclical ''Redemptoris mater''<ref name="RedMater" />
===Mary as protectress and intercessor=== {{see also|Mother of the Church}} [[File:Sano di Pietro. Madonna of Mercy.1440s Private coll..jpg|thumb|The ''[[Virgin of Mercy]]'' protecting a group of nuns under her mantle. [[Sano di Pietro]], 15th century.]] It was through Mary's intercession, through compassion for the hosts, at the marriage feast of Cana, that Jesus worked his first miracle.{{sfn|''Lumen gentium'', §61}}
The ''[[Catechism of the Catholic Church]]'' states: "From the most ancient times the Blessed Virgin has been honored with the title of 'Mother of God,' to whose protection the faithful fly in all their dangers and needs."<ref name="ccc971"/> The [[Eastern Catholic Churches]] observe the feast of the [[Intercession of the Theotokos]] in October.
Roman Catholic views of the Virgin Mary as refuge and advocate of sinners, protector from dangers and powerful intercessor with her Son, Jesus are expressed in prayers, artistic depictions, theology, and popular and devotional writings, as well as in the use of religious articles and images.<ref>Bunson, Matthew. ''Our Sunday Visitor's Catholic Almanac'', 2009 {{ISBN|1-59276-441-X}} p. 122</ref><ref>Laughlin, Corinna and Lee, Sara McGinnis. ''The Catholic Handbook for Visiting the Sick and Homebound''2010 {{ISBN|978-1-56854-886-9}} p. 4</ref> The earliest known prayer to Mary, the ''[[Sub tuum praesidium]]'', ("Under your protection") dates from about the 3rd century.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marian.org/mary/prayers/|title=Our Blessed Mother's Intercession - Marians of the Immaculate Conception|publisher=}}</ref>
The artistic depictions of the [[Virgin of Mercy]] portray the role of Mary as the protector of Christians, as she shelters them under her mantle. The Virgin of Mercy depictions sometimes include arrows raining from above, with the Virgin's cloak protecting the people.<ref>Hall, James. 1983, ''A History of Ideas and Images in Italian Art'' {{ISBN|0-7195-3971-4}} page 222</ref>
Catholics have continued to seek the protection of Mary as the [[Mother of Sorrows]] and relied on her intercession as the [[Queen of Heaven]] since the [[Middle Ages]].<ref>Campbell, James P., ''Mary and the Saints: Companions on the Journey'', 2001 {{ISBN|0-8294-1725-7}} pp. 41–45</ref> Building on that sentiment, popes have entrusted specific causes to the protection of the Virgin Mary. Pope [[Benedict XV]] entrusted the protection of the world through the intercession of Mary Queen of Peace during the [[World War I|First World War]] .<ref>Sri, Edward P., and Hahn, Scott. ''Queen Mother: A Biblical Theology of Mary's Queenship'', 2005 {{ISBN|1-931018-24-3}} p. 13</ref>
The [[Order of the Blessed Virgin Mary of Mercy]], also known as the order of ''Our Lady of Ransom'' or ''Order of Captives'' began in the 13th century in the [[Kingdom of Aragon]] (Spain) to ransom captive Christians (slaves) held in Muslim hands. The order now focuses on the role of the Virgin Mary as the protector of captives and prisoners.<ref>by Joseph, Chandlery Peter. ''Mary's Praise on Every Tongue: A Record of Homage Paid to Our Blessed Lady'', 2009 {{ISBN|1-113-16154-X}} p. 181</ref>
The depictions of [[Our Lady of Navigators]] arose from the prayers and devotions of Portuguese navigators, who saw the Virgin Mary as their protector during storms and other hazards. Prayers to Our Lady of Navigators are well known in South America, specially [[Brazil]], where its February 2 feast is an official holiday.<ref>Goucher, Candice Lee. 2007 ''World history: journeys from past to present'' {{ISBN|0-415-77137-4}} p. 102</ref><ref>del Rio, Vicente. ''Contemporary urbanism in Brazil'', 2009 {{ISBN|0-8130-3281-4}} p. 189</ref> [[The Virgin of the Navigators]], depicting ships under her mantle, is the earliest known painting whose subject is the discovery of the [[Americas]].<ref>Noble, John et al. ''Andalucía''. Lonely Planet, 2007, p. 100</ref><ref>Bedini, Silvio. 1991 ''The Christopher Columbus encyclopedia'' {{ISBN|0-13-142670-2}} p. 318</ref>
[[File:Guadalupano.jpg|thumb|150px|left|[[Miguel Hidalgo]]'s 1810 [[Our Lady of Guadalupe|Guadalupan]] flag.]] Both [[Miguel Hidalgo]] and [[Emiliano Zapata]] flew flags of [[Our Lady of Guadalupe]] as their protector, and Zapata's men wore the Guadalupan image around their necks and on their [[sombrero]]s.<ref>''Secular ritual'' by Falk Moore, Sally and Myerhoff, Barbara G., 1977 {{ISBN|90-232-1457-9}} p. 174</ref><ref>Brunk, Samuel. ''Emiliano Zapata'' 1995 {{ISBN|0-8263-1620-4}} p. 68</ref> In 1979 ceremony Pope [[John Paul II]] placed [[Mexico]] under the protection of the [[Virgin of Guadalupe]].<ref>Norman, Edward R., ''The Roman Catholic Church: an illustrated history'' ISBN p. 127</ref>
The prayer, the ''[[Memorare]]'' begins: "Remember O most gracious Virgin Mary, that never was it known that anyone who fled to Thy protection, implored Thy help or sought Thy intercession, was left unaided."<ref>Foster, David. ''Catholic Prayerbook: From Downside Abbey'', (2001), {{ISBN|0-567-08669-0}} p. 153.</ref>
Saint [[Louis de Montfort]] taught that God appointed Mary as "the dispenser of grace", and to receive grace from God, one can receive it through the hands of the Blessed Virgin, as a child receives from a mother.<ref name=Aumann /> ''[[Lumen gentium]]'' states: "This, however, is to be so understood that it neither takes away from nor adds anything to the dignity and efficaciousness of Christ the one Mediator."<ref name=ppvi/>
===Development of Marian doctrines=== The theological development of devotion to Mary begins with [[Justin Martyr]] (100–165) who articulated Mary’s role in salvation history as the Second Eve.<ref name=Ellington>[http://www.history.ac.uk/reviews/review/820 Spivey Ellington, Donna. review of ''Mother of God: A History of the Virgin Mary'', Reviews in History, (review no. 820)]</ref> This was followed up by [[Irenæus]], whom [[Herbert Thurston]] calls "the first theologian of the Virgin Mother".<ref name=Thurston/>
The Church's magisterium has identified four teachings about Mary as dogmas of faith. These include belief in her [[Virgin birth of Jesus|virginal conception of Jesus]], taught by the [[First Council of Nicaea]] in 325. The [[Council of Ephesus]] in 431 applied to her the description "[[Mother of God (Roman Catholic)|Mother of God]]", (''[[Theotokos]]''). The [[perpetual virginity of Mary]] was taught by the [[ecumenical council|ecumenical]] [[Second Council of Constantinople]] in 553, which described her as "ever virgin", and was expressed also, by the Lateran synod of October 649,<ref>Denzinger, [http://denzinger.patristica.net/#n200 256 (old numbering)], [http://catho.org/9.php?d=bxq 503 (new numbering)]</ref> The doctrine of the [[Immaculate Conception]] states that from the first moment of her existence Mary was without [[original sin]].<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/07674d.htm Holweck, Frederick. "Immaculate Conception." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 7. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1910. 4 April 2016</ref> This doctrine was proclaimed a dogma ''[[ex cathedra]]'' by Pope [[Pius IX]] in 1854. The dogma of the [[Assumption of Mary]], defined by Pope Pius XII in 1950, states that, at the end of her earthly life, she was assumed into [[heaven|heavenly glory]] body and soul.,<ref> [http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xii/apost_constitutions/documents/hf_p-xii_apc_19501101_munificentissimus-deus_en.html Pope Pius XII. ''Munificentissimus Deus'', 44]</ref>
===Liturgical aspects=== In the first three centuries the emphasis was on the veneration of [[martyrs]], as a continuation of the yearly celebrations of their death, e.g. as noted in the early Christian text on the [[Martyrdom of Polycarp]].<ref>''A brief history of saints'' by Lawrence Cunningham 2005 {{ISBN|1-4051-1402-9}} pages 16–19</ref>
In the Eastern traditions Mariology developed through liturgical veneration within the framework of the feasts relative to the Incarnation.<ref>[https://www.catholicculture.org/culture/library/view.cfm?recnum=1407 Samaha, John M., "Mary in Byzantine Liturgy", ''The Homiletic & Pastoral Review'', 1999]</ref> In the early part of the 3rd century, [[Hippolytus of Rome]] recorded the first liturgical reference to the Virgin Mary, as part of the ordination rite of a bishop.{{sfn|McNally, pp.68-69}} Marian feasts appeared in the 4th century, and the feast of the "Memory of Mary, Mother of God" was celebrated on August 15 in Jerusalem by the year 350.{{sfn|McNally, pp.68-69}}<ref>Adolf Adam, ''Liturgie,'' 1985, p.291</ref>
The Roman Catholic liturgy is one of the most important elements of [[Marian devotions]]. Many Marian feasts are superior to the feast days of the saints. The liturgical texts of the Marian feast days all link Mary to Jesus Christ.
==History==
===Early veneration=== [[File:Madonna catacomb.jpg|thumb|180px|left|Earliest fresco of the Virgin Mary, [[Catacomb of Priscilla]], 2nd century.<ref name= Lossky >Vladimir Lossky, 1982 ''The Meaning of Icons'' {{ISBN|978-0-913836-99-6}} page 173</ref>]] Mary, as the mother of Jesus, is documented in Roman [[catacombs]]: paintings from the first half of the 2nd century show her holding the [[Christ Child]].<ref name=Thurston/> Excavations in the crypt of [[St Peter's Basilica]] uncovered a very early fresco of Mary together with Saint Peter.<ref>M Guarducci Maria nelle epigrafi paleocristiane di Roma 1963, 248</ref> The Roman [[Priscilla catacomb]]s depict the oldest Marian paintings from the middle of the 2nd century:<ref>I Daoust, ''Marie dans les catacombes'', 1983</ref> Mary is shown with [[Jesus]] on her lap, a standing man with tunic left hand a book right hand a star over his head symbol of messiahs. Priscilla also has a depiction of the [[annunciation]].<ref name= Lossky /> The [[edict of Milan]] (AD 313) allowed Christians to worship openly. This new freedom also permitted literary development of the veneration of Mary, [[Hippolytus of Rome]] being an early example.{{sfn|McNally, pp.68-69}}<ref name="umer1">Bäumer 520</ref> [[Saint Ambrose]], who lived in Rome before going to Milan as its bishop, venerated Mary as an example of Christian life and is credited with starting a Marian cult of virginity in the 4th century.<ref>''A new history of ecclesiastical writers, Volumes 1–2' by Louis Ellies Du Pin et al 2010 {{ISBN|1-171-18698-3}} page 212</ref><!--His house in Rome is said to have been first female convent ''[[Sant'Ambrogio della Massima]]''.<ref name="umer1" /> -->
Marian veneration was theologically sanctioned with the adoption of the title ''[[Theotokos]]'' at the [[Council of Ephesus]] in 431. The earliest known churches dedicated to Mary were built shortly after that date, among these the [[Church of the Seat of Mary]] (''Kathisma'') near [[Mar Elias Monastery]], between Jerusalem and Bethlehem. The first [[Marian church]]es in Rome date from the 5th and 6th centuries: [[Santa Maria in Trastevere]], [[Santa Maria Antiqua]] and [[Santa Maria Maggiore]].<ref name=Thurston/> However, the very earliest church dedicated to the Virgin Mary still dates to the late 4th century in [[Syria]],{{dubious|date=April 2017}} where{{clarify|date=April 2017}}<!--"it's in Syria"... a little more info please?--> an inscription dedicating it to the [[Theotokos]] (Mother of God) was found among the ruins.<ref>''Butler's lives of the saints, Volume 1'' by Alban Butler, David Hugh Farmer, Paul Burns 2000 {{ISBN|0-86012-250-6}} p. 3</ref>
===Growth of Marian culture=== [[File:Piazza Esquilino, Santa Maria Maggiore.JPG|thumb|240px|[[Santa Maria Maggiore]], the first Marian church in [[Rome]], originally built between 430 and 440.<ref>''Rome'' by Yvonne Labande-Mailfert et al, 1961 ASIN: B0007E741C page 115</ref>]]
In the early Middle Ages, veneration of Mary was particularly expressed in monasteries, especially those of the [[Order of St. Benedict|Benedictines]]. Chants such as [[Ave Maris Stella]] and the [[Salve Regina]] emerged and became staples of monastic plainsong.<ref>Osborne, John L. "Early Medieval Painting in San Clemente, Rome: The Madonna and Child in the Niche" ''Gesta'' 20.2 (1981:299–310) and (note 9) referencing T. Klauser, Rom under der Kult des Gottesmutter Maria, ''Jahrbuch für der Antike und Christentum'' 15 (1972:120–135).</ref> In the 8th century, [[Little Office of Our Lady|The Little Office of the Blessed Virgin Mary]] developed from the monks' practice of praying the [[Canonical hours]]. The Carolingians encouraged Marian piety by the celebration of Marian feast days and the dedication of churches in her honor.<ref name=Ellington/> Devotional practices grew in number.
The [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] period saw the construction of major [[Roman Catholic Marian churches|Marian churches]], such as [[Speyer Cathedral]] (also known as the [[Mariendom]]) in [[Speyer]], Germany, and [[Our Lady of Flanders]] Cathedral in [[Tournai, Belgium]]. From the year 1000 onward more and more churches, including many of Europe's greatest cathedrals were dedicated to Mary. Gothic cathedrals, such as [[Notre Dame de Paris]] as well as [[Our Lady of Chartres]] near Paris, were major masterworks of the time. Construction of [[Santa Maria Assunta, Siena|Santa Maria Assunta]] Cathedral in [[Siena, Italy]] and [[Notre-Dame Cathedral, Luxembourg]] increased the number of [[Roman Catholic Marian churches|churches devoted to the Virgin Mary]].
The 12th and 13th centuries saw an extraordinary growth of the cult of the Virgin in Western Europe, inspired in part by the writings of theologians such as [[Bernard of Clairvaux]]. The movement found its grandest expression in the French cathedrals, often dedicated to “Our Lady", such as [[Notre-Dame de Paris]] and [[Notre-Dame de Bayeux]] among others.<ref name=Heilbrunn>{{cite web|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/virg/hd_virg.htm|title=The Cult of the Virgin Mary in the Middle Ages|author=Department of Medieval Art and The Cloisters|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art}}</ref> [[Our Lady of Walsingham|Walsingham]] and other places of Marian pilgrimage developed large popular followings. At the height of the pilgrimage movement in the 11th and 12th centuries, hundreds of people were traveling almost constantly from one Marian shrine to the next.<ref>''Renaissance and Reformation'' by William Roscoe Estep 1986 {{ISBN|0-8028-0050-5}}, page 7.</ref>
By the 14th century, Mary had become greatly popular as a compassionate intercessor and protector of humanity, and during the great plagues (such as the [[Black Death]]) her help was sought against the just judgment of God.<ref>''Daily life during the Black Death'' by Joseph Patrick Byrne 2006 {{ISBN|0-313-33297-5}}, page 86.</ref> The [[Renaissance]] witnessed a dramatic growth in venerative Marian art.<ref>''Mary in Western art'' by Timothy Verdon, Filippo Rossi 2005 {{ISBN|0-9712981-9-X}}, page 203.</ref>
By the 16th century, the [[Protestant Reformation]] had introduced a tide against Marian venerations in Europe.<ref>''Renaissance and Reformation'' by William Roscoe Estep 1986 {{ISBN|0-8028-0050-5}} pages 140–144</ref> However, at the same time new Marian devotions were starting in Latin America based on Saint [[Juan Diego]]'s 1531 reported vision of [[Our Lady of Guadalupe]]. The ensuing Marian pilgrimages have continued to date and the Marian Basilica on [[Tepeyac Hill]] remains the most visited Catholic shrine in the world.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web | url = http://www.ewtn.com/library/MARY/ZSHRINE.HTM | publisher = ZENIT International News Agency | accessdate = October 1, 2010 | title = Shrine of Gualdalupe Most Popular in World}}</ref> In the 17th and 18th centuries writings by the saints, coupled with papal encouragements, increased the growth of Marian devotions, and gave rise to the definition and declaration of new Marian doctrines.<ref>''The encyclopedia of Christianity, Volume 3'' by Erwin Fahlbusch, Geoffrey William Bromiley 2003 {{ISBN|90-04-12654-6}} pages 406–409</ref>
Marian culture continues to develop within the Catholic Church. In 1974, after 4 years of preparation, [[Pope Paul VI]] issued the Apostolic Letter ''[[Marialis Cultus]]''. In this document, (which was subtitled ''For the Right Ordering and Development of Devotion to the Blessed Virgin Mary'') Paul VI not only discussed the history of Marian devotions but also overviewed their rationale and provided suggestions for their future direction, emphasising their theological and pastoral value.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/paul_vi/apost_exhortations/documents/hf_p-vi_exh_19740202_marialis-cultus_en.html | title = Marialis Cultus at the Vatican website | publisher = Vatican.va | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://campus.udayton.edu/mary/resources/documents/MC.html | title = University of Dayton | publisher = Campus.udayton.edu | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref>
==Catholic saints and veneration of Mary== {{Main|Mariology of the saints}}
Roman Catholic devotions have relied on the writings of numerous saints throughout history who have attested to the central role of Mary in God's plan of salvation.<ref>Butler, Alban ''Lives of the saints, Volume 1'' 2007 {{ISBN|1-60506-312-6}} p. 429</ref>
Early saints included [[Irenaeus of Lyons]] in the 2nd century who was perhaps the earliest of the Church Fathers to write systematically about the Virgin Mary, and he set out a forthright account of her role in the economy of salvation.<ref>Osborn, Eric Francis. ''Irenaeus of Lyons'' 2001 {{ISBN|0-521-80006-4}} p. 112</ref><ref>Tertullian, ''De Carne Christi'' 17</ref>[[Ambrose of Milan]] (339–397) based the veneration of Mary not only on her virginity but also on her extraordinary courage.<ref>Neumann, Charles William. ''The Virgin Mary in the works of Saint Ambrose'', 1962 ASIN: B0007J9CX0 p. 264</ref><ref>Ambrose, [[CSEL]] 32, 505, and De inst. Virginum 49</ref>
In the Middle Ages, [[Bernhard of Clairvaux]] highlighted her virginity and humility as the basis for her veneration.<ref>Schäfer, Peter. ''Mirror of His beauty'', 2002 {{ISBN|0-691-09068-8}} p. 157</ref><ref>Schmaus, Michael. ''Mariologie, Katholische Dogmatik'', München Vol V, 1955207 p. 207</ref> A particularly significant contribution to Mariology came from John [[Duns Scotus]] who in the 13th century defended the doctrine of the Immaculate Conception.<ref>Wolter, Allan B. and O'Neill, Blane. ''John Duns Scotus: Mary's Architect'', Franciscan Press, Illinois, 1983, p.1</ref> Scotus identified the key theological foundations which led to the declaration of the dogma of Immaculate Conception centuries later.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/john_paul_ii/speeches/2002/february/documents/hf_jp-ii_spe_20020216_frati-minori_en.html | title = Address of John Paul II to the Members of the Scotus Commission | publisher = Vatican.va | date = February 16, 2002 | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref>
In the 16th century, Saint [[Ignatius of Loyola]] instructed the Jesuits to preserve ''[[Madonna della Strada]]'', which was later enshrined in the [[Church of the Gesu]] in Rome.<ref>[http://www.americamagazine.org/content/culture.cfm?cultureid=83 Waldrop, Gregory. "Object of Devotion: The story of a dramatic restoration". ''America'', October 2010]</ref> [[Filippo Neri]], a contemporary of Ignatius, is credited with the innovation of daily Marian devotions during the [[May devotions to the Blessed Virgin Mary|month of May]].<ref>Venturoli, A., ''S. Filippo Neri'', Roma, 1988, p. 117</ref>
In his classic book ''[[The Glories of Mary]]'', [[Alphonsus Liguori]] explained how God gave Mary to mankind as the "Gate of Heaven", quoting [[Saint Bonaventure]], "No one can enter Heaven unless by Mary, as though through a door."<ref>Liguori, Alphonsus. ''The Glories of Mary'', Liguori Publications, 1868, {{ISBN|0-7648-0664-5}} p. 623</ref> [[Louis de Montfort]]'s book ''[[True Devotion to Mary]]'' synthesized many of the writings of earlier saints. His approach of "total consecration to Jesus Christ through Mary" had a strong impact on Marian devotion both in popular piety and in the spirituality of [[religious institute]]s.

The earliest Christian feasts that relate to Mary grew out of the cycle of feasts that celebrated the [[Nativity of Jesus]]. By the 7th century a feast dedicated to Mary was celebrated just before Christmas in the churches of [[Milan]] and [[Ravenna]] in Italy.<ref name =MaryClayton>''The Cult of the Virgin Mary in Anglo-Saxon England'' by Mary Clayton 2003 {{ISBN|0-521-53115-2}} pages 26–37</ref> Over time, the number of feasts (and the associated [[titles of Mary]]) and the venerative practices that accompany them increased and today the [[Catholic Church]] has more Marian feasts, titles, and venerative practices than any other Christian body.<ref name="FrankFlinn" /> Marian feasts have continued to be developed in the Catholic Church, e.g. the feast of the [[Queenship of Mary]] was declared in the 1954 in the papal encyclical ''[[Ad Caeli Reginam]]'' by pope [[Pius XII]].<ref name="AdCaeli">{{cite web | url = http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/pius_xii/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-xii_enc_11101954_ad-caeli-reginam_en.html | work = Ad Caeli Reginam | publisher = Vatican | accessdate = October 4, 2010 | title = Encyclical of Pope Pius XII on Proclaiming the Queenship of Mary|author=Pope Pius XII}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|date=8 November 1954|title=Religion: The Queenship of Mary|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,857668,00.html|magazine=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|doi=|pmid=|access-date=6 June 2016|registration=yes}}</ref>
[[File:Azzano processione santo rosario.jpg|thumb|240px|A [[Feast of Our Lady of the Rosary]] procession during October in [[Bergamo]], Italy]]
[[Catherine of Siena]], adopted the custom of dedicating Saturday to Mary. The month of October was established as the "month of the Rosary" by Pope [[Leo XIII]], who recommended daily Rosary devotions in October.<ref>''The encyclopedia of Christianity, Volume 4'' by Erwin Fahlbusch, Geoffrey William Bromiley 2005 {{ISBN|0-8028-2416-1}} page 575</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.vatican.va/holy_father/leo_xiii/encyclicals/documents/hf_l-xiii_enc_22091891_octobri-mense_en.html | work = Octobri Mense | publisher = Vatican | accessdate = October 4, 2010 | title = Encyclical of Pope Leo XIII on the Rosary|author=Pope Leo XIII}}</ref>
During the month of May, [[May devotions to the Blessed Virgin Mary]] take place in many Catholic regions. These may include the singing of Marian anthems, crowning of statues of Mary with floral wreaths, readings from [[scripture]]s, a [[sermon]], and or presentation by local choirs.<ref>''Maiden and Mother: Prayers, Hymns, Devotions, and Songs to the Beloved Beloved Virgin Mary Throughout the Year'' by M. M. Miles, Margaret R. Miles 2001 {{ISBN|0-86012-305-7}} page</ref><ref>''Handbook of Prayers'' by James Socías 2006 {{ISBN|0-87973-579-1}} page 483</ref> The month is also associated with reflection on the Virgin Mary's role as the ideal disciple who sheds light on the Christian way of life, and theologian [[Karl Rahner]] stated: "When we are involved in our May Devotions, we are engaged in a Christian understanding of the human situation."<ref>''Truly Our Sister: A Theology of Mary in the Communion of Saints'' by Elizabeth A. Johnson 2006 {{ISBN|0-8264-1827-9}} page 97</ref> [[File:Virgen Andacollo.jpg|thumb|240px|A [[Our Lady of Andacollo|Feast of Our Lady of Andacollo]] procession in [[Chile]], 1838]] The Roman Catholic Church celebrates three Marian [[solemnity|solemnities]] which are also [[Holy day of obligation|holy days of obligation]] in many countries during the liturgical year<ref name="usccb.org">{{cite web | url = http://www.usccb.org/liturgy/current/2010cal.pdf | title = National Calendar of the USA on-line | format = PDF | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref> (in liturgical order): * December 8 [[Immaculate Conception|Feast of the Immaculate Conception]] * January 1 [[Mother of God (Roman Catholic)|Mary, Mother of God]] * August 15 [[Assumption of Mary|The Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary]] Among the other prominent Marian feast days and memorials in the [[General Roman Calendar]] of the Catholic Church are:<ref name="usccb.org" /> <!--

Archdiocesan Museum, [[Wrocław]]. ]] A large number of titles to honor Mary or ask for her intercession are used by Roman Catholics.<ref>''Encyclopedia of Catholicism by Frank K. Flinn'', J. Gordon Melton 2007 {{ISBN|0-8160-5455-X}} pages 443–444</ref> While ''Mater Dei'' (i.e. "Mother of God" as confirmed by the [[First Council of Ephesus]], 431) is common in Latin, a large number of other titles have been used by Roman Catholics – far more than any other Christians.<ref name=FrankFlinn /><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/npnf214.x.xvi.i.html | title = The Canons of the Two Hundred Holy and Blessed Fathers Who Met at Ephesus | publisher = Ccel.org | date = June 1, 2005 | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>''The Christian theology reader'' by Alister E. McGrath 2006 {{ISBN|1-4051-5358-X}} page 273</ref>
Titles used to refer to the Virgin Mary throughout history, at times reflect the changing attitudes towards her. ''[[Dominus (title)|Domina]]'' (lady), ''Regina'' (queen) and ''[[Our Lady, Star of the Sea|Stella Maris]]'' (star of the sea) are some of the early titles of Mary, of which Regina is the earliest. ''Domina'' and ''Sella Maris'' are found in [[Jerome]] who perhaps originated the [[etymology]] of Mary as ''Stella Maris'' in the 5th century. While the early emphasis in Stella Maris was on Mary as the Star that bore Christ, by the 9th century, the attention had focused on Mary herself, as indicated in the hymn [[Ave Maris Stella]]. By the 11th century, Mary herself had emerged as the star that acted as a guiding light.<ref>''The Cult of the Virgin Mary in Anglo-Saxon England'' by Mary Clayton 2003 {{ISBN|0-521-53115-2}} pages 249–252</ref> By the 13th century, as [[Mariology]] was growing, Saint [[Anthony of Padua]] had composed [[Mary Our Queen]].<ref>''The greatest Marian prayers: their history, meaning, and usage'' by Anthony M. Buono 1999 {{ISBN|0-8189-0861-0}} page 124</ref> Titles continue to be interpreted, e.g. [[Queen of Heaven]] was further elaborated in 1954 in the papal encyclical ''[[Ad Caeli Reginam]]'' by pope [[Pius XII]].<ref name="AdCaeli" />

==Music== {{Main|Roman Catholic Marian music|Hymns to Mary}} {{listen|filename=Alma Redemptoris Mater.ogg | title = Alma Redemptoris Mater|description=Marian antiphon sung at Compline and Lauds between the First Sunday of Advent and Candlemas | format = [[Ogg]]}}
===Antiphons=== The [[Liturgy of the Hours]] includes several offices to be sung, including [[Compline]]. At the close of this office, one of four ''[[Marian antiphon]]s'' is sung. These songs, ''[[Alma redemptoris mater]], ''[[Ave Regina caelorum]]'', ''[[Regina caeli]]'', and ''[[Salve Regina]]'', have been described as "among the most beautiful creations of the late Middle Ages".<ref>Willi Apel, ''Gregorian Chant'' 1958 {{ISBN|0-253-20601-4}} p. 404.</ref><ref>''Music In Western Civilisation'' by Craig M. Wright, Bryan R. Simm 2005 {{ISBN|0-495-00867-2}} page 137</ref>
One of the earliest Marian compositions is the popular [[Salve Regina]] in [[Latin]] from a Benedictine monk, which exists in several Gregorian versions. [[Hermann of Reichenau]] (July 18, 1013 – September 24, 1054), composed the [[Alma redemptoris mater]] and hymns to Mary became part of daily life at monasteries such as the [[Benedictine]] [[Abbey of Cluny]] in France.<ref name=ChristianRaab>:''The Tradition of Catholic Prayer'' by Christian Raab, Harry Hagan 2007 {{ISBN|0-8146-3184-3}} page 234</ref><ref>{{cite book | url = https://books.google.com/?id=AgaDx-NSiMYC&pg=RA4-PA472&dq=Alma+Redemptoris+Mater#v=onepage&q=Alma%20Redemptoris%20Mater&f=false | title = Handbook of Prayers | author = James Socías | year = 2006 |isbn = 978-0-87973-579-1 | page = 472 | publisher = | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref>
While the date of the composition of [[Ave Regina Coelorum]] is uncertain, conjecture that it antedates the fourth century seems to be without any warrant of external or internal evidence. It is found in the St. Alban's Book of the twelfth century.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/02149b.htm Henry, Hugh. "Ave Regina." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 2. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 11 October 2016</ref> The [[Regina Coeli]] has been traced back to the twelfth century.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12718b.htm Henry, Hugh. "Regina Coeli (Queen of Heaven)." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 12. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1911. 11 October 2016</ref>
It is difficult to trace the beginning of non-[[Gregorian chant|Gregorian]] Marian liturgical music.<ref>''Harvard dictionary of music'' by Willi Apel 1944 {{ISBN|0-674-37501-7}} pages 355–356</ref> In 1277 [[Pope Nicholas III]] prescribed rules for liturgy in Roman churches.<ref>Bäumer, 652</ref><ref>''Songs of the dove and the nightingale: sacred and secular music c.900-c.1600'' by Greta Mary Hair, Robyn E. Smith 1995 {{ISBN|2-88449-141-4}} page 63</ref> In the [[Graduale Romanum]], [[Kyriale]] IX and X are both for Marian feasts. Over the centuries, Marian master pieces have continued to appear, e.g. [[Mozart]]'s Coronation Mass.<ref>''Catholic Music Through the Ages'' by Edward Schaefer 2008 {{ISBN|1-59525-020-4}} page 100</ref> The [[list of compositions by Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina]] includes numerous Marian masses: ''Salve Regina'', ''Alma Redemptoris'', ''Assumpta est Maria'', ''Regina coeli'', ''de beata Virgine'', ''Ave Regina coelorum'', ''Descendit Angelus Domini'', and ''O Virgo simul et Mater''.<ref>''Harvard dictionary of music'' by Willi Apel 1944 {{ISBN|0-674-37501-7}} pages 29 and 66</ref> [[Joseph Haydn]] wrote several Marian [[Musical composition|compositions]] including two famous Marian Masses.<ref>Missa in honorem Beatissimae Virginis Mariae, No. 5 in E flat major, also known as the Grosse Orgelmesse (Great Organ Mass) (H. 22/4) (1766) and [[Missa Cellensis in honorem Beatissimae Virginis Mariae]] No. 3 in C major, (H. 22/5) (1766–73)</ref>
[[Hymns to Mary|Marian hymns]] include ''O Mary, we Crown Thee With Blossoms Today'', ''[[Hail Queen of Heaven, the Ocean Star|Hail Queen of Heaven]]'', the ''[[Queen of Heaven|Regina Coeli]]'', and the ''[[Ave Maria]]''.<ref>Geoghegan. G.P. ''A Collection of My Favorite Prayers'', 2006 {{ISBN|1-4116-9457-0}} pages 31, 45, 70, 86, 127</ref>
==Prayers== {{see also|Marian litanies}}
Author Emily Shapcote lists 150 Marian poems and hymns in her book ''Mary the Perfect Woman''.<ref>''Mary the Perfect Woman: One Hundred and Fifty Rhythms in Honor of the Mystical Life of Our Lady'' by Emily Mary Shapcote 2009 {{ISBN|1-103-66388-7}} pages xxii–xxxiii [https://books.google.com/books?id=d-sb0izzxnAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22mary+the+perfect+woman%22&hl=en&ei=_F-aTN-AHIaRswbcwaygBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> Such prayers and poems go as far back as the 3rd century, but enjoyed a rapid growth during the 11th and 12th centuries. Some of the best poetry written in honor of the Blessed virgin comes from this period of the [[Middle Ages]].<ref name=MMiles>''Maiden and Mother: Prayers, Hymns, Devotions, and Songs to the Beloved Virgin Mary Throughout the Year'' by Margaret R. Miles 2001 {{ISBN|0-86012-305-7}} pages vii–x [https://books.google.com/books?id=PE6MlDNijNAC&pg=PR8&dq=%22Regina+Caelorum%22+mary+poem+maiden+mother&hl=en&ei=n1KaTMTrDM_DswazmdyOBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref>
"Because of Mary's singular cooperation with the action of the Holy Spirit, the Church loves to pray in communion with the Virgin Mary, to magnify with her the great things the Lord has done for her, and to entrust supplications and praises to her.<ref>{{CCC|2682}}</ref>
The earliest known Marian prayer is the [[Sub tuum praesidium]], or ''Beneath Thy Protection'', a text for which was rediscovered in 1917 on a papyrus in Egypt dated to c. 250.<ref name="Burke, Raymond L. 2008 page 178">Burke, Raymond L.; et al. (2008). ''Mariology: A Guide for Priests, Deacons, Seminarians, and Consecrated Persons'' {{ISBN|978-1-57918-355-4}} page 178</ref><ref name="Tim S. Perry page 142">''Mary for evangelicals'' by Tim S. Perry, William J. Abraham 2006 {{ISBN|0-8308-2569-X}} page 142</ref> The papyrus contains the prayer in [[Greek language|Greek]] and is the earliest known reference to the title [[Theotokos]] (confirmed by the [[First Council of Ephesus|Council of Ephesus]] in 431):<ref>''The encyclopedia of Christianity, Volume 3'' by Erwin Fahlbusch, Geoffrey William Bromiley 2003 {{ISBN|90-04-12654-6}} page 406 [https://books.google.com/books?id=7ly4DgtT3LkC&pg=PA406&dq=Sub+tuum+praesidium+history&hl=en&ei=2E-aTMvAOoiVswb8hZ2JBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=Sub%20tuum%20praesidium%20history&f=false]</ref>
<blockquote> Beneath your compassion, We take refuge, O Mother of God: do not despise our petitions in time of trouble: but rescue us from dangers, only pure, only blessed one. </blockquote>
The ''[[Little Office of Our Lady|Little Office of the Blessed Virgin Mary]]'' probably originated as a [[monastic]] devotion around the middle of the eighth century.<ref name=toke>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/09294a.htm Toke, Leslie. "Little Office of Our Lady." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 9. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1910. 1 October 2012</ref> It is a variation of the Common of the Blessed Virgin Mary in the [[Liturgy of the Hours]] (Divine Office). It may have originally been put together to be prayed in connection with the Votive Masses of Our Lady on Saturday, which were written by [[Alcuin]], the liturgical master of Charlemagne’s court.<ref name=dayton>{{cite web|url=https://www.udayton.edu/imri/mary/l/little-office-what-is.php|title=Little Office, What is : University of Dayton, Ohio|publisher=}}</ref> The Little Office did not come into general use before the tenth century.
During the 11th century, as the number of monasteries grew, so did Marian prayers. There is little or no trace of the [[Hail Mary]] as an accepted devotional formula before about 1050. All the evidence suggests that it took its rise from certain versicles and responsories occurring in the Little Office or Cursus of the Blessed Virgin which just at that time was coming into favour among the monastic orders. Two Anglo-Saxon manuscripts at the British Museum, one of which may be as old as the year 1030, show that the words "Ave Maria" etc. and "benedicta tu in mulieribus et benedictus fructus ventris tui" occurred in almost every part of the Cursus, and though it is not clear that these clauses were at first joined together so as to make one prayer, there is conclusive evidence that this had come to pass only a very little later.<ref>Thurston, Herbert. "The Hail Mary" ''The Month'', Nov., 1901, pp. 486-8</ref> As regards the addition of the word "Jesus," it is commonly said that this was due to the initiative of Pope Urban IV (1261) although the evidence does not seem sufficiently clear to warrant positive statement on the point.<ref name=Thurston/> This was the prayer as known to [[Thomas Aquinas]] when he gave a Lenten sermon on the "Salutation of the Blessed Virgin" in 1273.<ref>Thomas Aquinas. ''The Three Greatest Prayers'', (Laurence Shapcote, trans.) Burns, Oates & Washburn, Ltd. (London 1937)</ref> By the fourteenth century it was not uncommon to conclude with an appeal for sinners and especially for help at the hour of death. Official recognition of the Ave Maria in its complete form was finally given in the Roman Breviary of 1568.<ref name=Thurston/>
[[File:Jean-François Millet Angelus.jpg|thumb|"The Angelus", Jean-François Millet]] [[Three Hail Marys]] is a traditional Roman Catholic devotional practice of reciting three Hail Marys as a petition for purity and other virtues. The practice of saying three Hail Marys in the evening somewhere about sunset had become general throughout Europe in the first half of the fourteenth century and it was recommended by [[Pope John XXII]] in 1318. The practice was observed by [[Franciscan]]s and eventually developed into the [[Angelus]] prayer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01486b.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Angelus|publisher=}}</ref>
The Angelus is a prayer commemorating the Incarnation. It originated with the 11th-century monastic custom of reciting three Hail Marys during the evening, or Compline bell. It was traditionally recited in Roman Catholic churches, convents, and monasteries three times daily: 6:00 am, noon, and 6:00 pm and is usually accompanied by the ringing of the Angelus bell, which is a call to prayer.<ref>[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01486b.htm Thurston, Herbert. "Angelus." The Catholic Encyclopedia] Vol. 1. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1907. 13 October 2016</ref>
In the 12th century [[Bernard of Clairvaux]] gave sermons (De duodecim stellis), from which an extract has been taken by the Roman Catholic Church and used in the ''Offices of the Compassion'' and of the ''Seven Dolours''. Saint Bernard wrote: "Take away Mary, this star of the sea, the sea truly great and wide: what is left but enveloping darkness and the shadow of death and the densest blackness?"<ref name=ChristianRaab /> There are pious meditations on the ''[[Hail Mary|Ave Maria]]'' and the ''[[Salve Regina]]'', usually attributed either to [[Anselm of Lucca|St. Anselm of Lucca]] (d. 1080) or [[Bernard of Clairvaux|St. Bernard]]; and also in the large book "De laudibus B. Mariae Virginis" (Douai, 1625) by Richard de Saint-Laurent.
Other famous Marian prayers include the [[Magnificat]], and the [[Litany of the Blessed Virgin Mary]].
The mostly anonymous Middle English Lyrics of the Later Middle Ages show passionate forms of personal worship, known as affective devotion. The lyrics, reflecting the theology, depict Mary as not just the woman but also the ideal that all humanity should strive for.
Mary’s humility is one of the qualities highlighted by in the Middle English Lyrics. The lyric “Gabriel, from hevenë king/ sent to the maidë swetë” is an excellent example of Mary’s humility. The lyric’s author builds upon this theme throughout the lyric. The second stanza “Mildëliche him gan answere/ The midlë maiden thannë." The theme of humity is fully developed in the third stanza;
<blockquote>
When the maiden understood/ And th’angles wordës herdë,/ Mildëliche with mildë mod/ To th’angel she answerdë:/ ‘Our Lordës thew-maiden i-wis/ Ich am, that her-aboven is./ Anentës me/ Fulforthëd be/ Thy, sawë;/ That Ich, sithe His wil is,/ Maiden, withouten lawë,/ Of moder have the blis. <ref>Anonymous (2013). Number 77 “Gabriel, from hevenë king.” In T. Duncan (Ed.), Medieval English Lyrics and Carols. Cambridge: D. S. Brewer.</ref> </blockquote>
==Devotions== {{Main|Marian devotions}} {{see also|Rosary|Scapular|Rosary and scapular|Rosary devotions and spirituality}}
[[File:Rosary&scapular.jpg|thumb|[[Rosary and scapular]]]]
The term "[[wikt:devotion|devotion]]s" is commonly understood to refer to those external practices of piety by which the faith of an individual finds expression.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/ccdds/documents/rc_con_ccdds_doc_20020513_vers-direttorio_en.html|title=Directory on popular piety and the liturgy. Principles and guidelines|publisher=Congregation for Divine Worship|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> Such prayers or acts may be accompanied by specific requests for Mary's [[Intercession of saints|intercession]] with [[God in Christianity|God]].<ref>Marmion, Columba. ''Christ, the Ideal of the Priest'', 2006 {{ISBN|0-85244-657-8}} p. 332</ref><ref name=Burke667 >Burke, Raymond L.; et al. (2008). Mariology: A Guide for Priests, Deacons, Seminarians, and Consecrated Persons {{ISBN|978-1-57918-355-4}} pages 667-679</ref> Devotion to the Virgin Mary does not, however, amount to worship - which is reserved for God.
A wide range of [[Marian devotion]]s are followed by Catholics ranging from simple [[Rosary]] recitations to formalized, multi-day Novenas to activities which do not involve any prayers, such the wearing of scapulars or maintaining a [[Mary garden]].<ref>Ann Ball, 2003 ''Encyclopedia of Catholic Devotions and Practices'' {{ISBN|0-87973-910-X}} pages 11 and 341</ref> Two well known Marian devotions are the Rosary recitation and the wearing of the Brown Scapular. Following their joint growth in the 18th and 19th centuries, by the early 20th century the [[Rosary]] and the devotional [[Scapular]] had gained such a strong following among Catholics worldwide that the [[Catholic Encyclopedia]] of 1914 stated: "''Like the Rosary, the Brown Scapular has become the badge of the devout Catholic''."<ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Scapular}}</ref> In his encyclical ''[[Rosarium Virginis Mariae]]'' [[Pope John Paul II]] emphasized the importance of the Rosary. The [[Roman Catholic Mariology|Mariological]] basis of the Scapular devotion is effectively the same as Marian consecration, as discussed in the dogmatic constitution ''[[Lumen gentium]]'' of the [[Second Vatican Council]], namely the role of the Virgin Mary as "''the mother to us in the order of grace''" which allows her to intercede for "''the gift of eternal salvation''".<ref name="vatican.va">Vatican website: ''[[Lumen gentium]]'' No 61 and No 62 [http://www.vatican.va/archive/hist_councils/ii_vatican_council/documents/vat-ii_const_19641121_lumen-gentium_en.html]</ref> The same Council decree clarified that the many ways in which Mary can encourage and assist us "neither takes away from nor adds anything to the dignity and efficaciousness of Christ the one Mediator."<ref>''[[Lumen gentium]]'' 62</ref>
[[Roman Catholic]] tradition includes specific prayers and devotions as ''[[Acts of Reparation to the Virgin Mary]]'' for insults that she suffers. The [[Raccolta]] Roman Catholic prayer book (approved by a Decree of 1854, and published by the [[Holy See]] in 1898) includes a number of such prayers. These prayers do not involve a petition for a living or deceased beneficiary, but aim to ''[[Acts of reparation|repair the sins]] of others'' against the Virgin Mary.<ref>Ann Ball, 2003 ''Encyclopedia of Catholic Devotions and Practices ''{{ISBN|0-87973-910-X}}</ref><ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Raccolta}}</ref><ref>Joseph P. Christopher et al., 2003 ''The Raccolta'' St Athanasius Press {{ISBN|978-0-9706526-6-9}}</ref>
===Consecration and entrustment to Mary=== {{Main|Consecration and entrustment to Mary}} For centuries, Marian devotions among Roman Catholics have included many examples of personal or collective acts of [[consecration]] and entrustment to the Virgin Mary; the Latin terms ''oblatio'', ''servitus'', ''commendatio'', and ''dedicatio'' were used in this context.<ref name="VaticanEntrust">{{cite web | url = http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/congregations/ccdds/documents/rc_con_ccdds_doc_20020513_vers-direttorio_en.html#Chapter%20Five | title = Veneration of the Holy Mother of God, item 204 | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref> [[Consecration and entrustment to Mary|Consecration]] is an act by which a person is dedicated to a sacred service, or an act which separates an object, location or region from a common and profane mode to one for sacred use.<ref name="CathEncyConsecration">{{cite web|url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04276a.htm|title=CATHOLIC ENCYCLOPEDIA: Consecration|publisher=}}</ref><ref name= Murphy96 >''Mary's Immaculate Heart'' by John F. Murphy 2007 {{ISBN|1-4067-3409-8}} pages 96–103</ref>
The Catholic Church makes it clear that "...the faithful should be carefully instructed about the practice of consecration to the Blessed Virgin Mary...it is, in reality, only analogously a 'consecration to God,' and should be expressed in a correct liturgical manner: to the Father, through Christ in the Holy Spirit, imploring the intercession of the Blessed Virgin Mary, to whom we entrust ourselves completely, so as to keep our baptismal commitments and live as her children."<ref name="VaticanEntrust" />
Individuals declaring their "entrustment" to Mary seek her intercession before God through her son Jesus Christ, for she herself has no divine power.<ref name="CathEncyConsecration" /><ref name="Murphy96"/> In Catholic teachings, consecration to Mary does not diminish or substitute the love of God, but enhances it, for all consecration is ultimately made to God.<ref name="CatholicismAnswerTrigilioBrighenti">''The Catholicism Answer Book'' by John Trigilio, Kenneth Brighenti 2007 {{ISBN|1-4022-0806-5}} page 325</ref>
In modern times, [[John Paul II|Pope John Paul II]] clarified consecration to Mary in his 1987 encyclical, ''Redemptoris mater'', in which he stated, "Mary's motherhood...is a gift which Christ himself makes personally to every individual."<ref name="RedMater" />
==Catholic view of Marian apparitions== {{Main|Marian apparitions}}
Many ''[[Marian apparition]]'' have been reported by believers, including [[Our Lady of Lourdes]], [[Our Lady of Guadalupe]], and [[Our Lady of Fatima]].<ref name=Freze >Michael Freze, 1993, ''Voices, Visions, and Apparitions'', OSV Publishing {{ISBN|0-87973-454-X}} pages 257–265</ref><ref>Short Biography of Padre Pio http://www.padrepiodevotions.org/index.asp?pagename=biography {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012172959/http://www.padrepiodevotions.org/index.asp?pagename=biography |date=October 12, 2007 }}</ref><ref>The book ''Mother Maria Pierina'' by Maria Rigamonti http://www.cenacle.co.uk/products.asp?partno=B0532</ref> In some cases (e.g. Saint [[Padre Pio]] or Sister [[Maria Pierina|Maria Pierina De Micheli]]) these have involved [[visions of Jesus and Mary]] and sometimes include a spoken element.
The official position of the [[Holy See]] is that while the [[Holy Office]] has approved a few apparitions of the Virgin Mary, Roman Catholics at large are not required to believe them. However, many Catholics express belief in Marian apparitions.<ref>''Habits of Devotion'' by James M. O'Toole 2005 {{ISBN|0-8014-7255-5}} page 121</ref> This has included popes, e.g. four popes, i.e. [[Pope Pius XII]], [[Pope John XXIII]], [[Pope Paul VI]], and [[Pope John Paul II]] have supported the [[Our Lady of Fátima]] messages as supernatural.{{citation needed|date=November 2010}} [[Pope John Paul II]] was particularly attached to Fátima and credited Our Lady of Fátima with saving his life after he was shot in Rome on the Feast Day of Our Lady of Fátima in May 1981. He donated the bullet that wounded him on that day to the Roman Catholic sanctuary at [[Fátima, Portugal|Fátima]] [[Portugal]].<ref name=Freze /><ref>McNally, Terrence, ''What Every Catholic Should Know about Mary'' {{ISBN|1-4415-1051-6}} page 166</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/16/world/pope-donates-bullet-to-fatima-sanctuary.html | title = NY Times |location=Czestochowa (Poland); Fatima (Portugal) | publisher = NY Times | date = May 16, 1984 | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref>
As a historical pattern, Vatican approval seems to have followed general acceptance of a vision by well over a century in most cases. According to Father Salvatore M. Perrella of the [[Marianum|Mariunum Pontifical Institute]] in Rome, of the 295 reported apparitions studied by the [[Holy See]] through the centuries only 12 have been approved, the latest being in May 2008.<ref name="catholicnewsagency1" /><ref name="catholicnewsagency2" /><ref>Vatican News on [[Benoite Rencurel]] http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/avantgo/new.php?n=12546 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081212214242/http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/avantgo/new.php?n=12546 |date=December 12, 2008 }}</ref><ref>Catholic News on [[Benoite Rencurel]] http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=27848 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513224745/http://www.catholic.org/international/international_story.php?id=27848 |date=May 13, 2008 }}</ref>
==Veneration through Marian art==
{{Main|Marian art in the Catholic Church}}
[[File:Geertgen tot Sint Jans - The Glorification of the Virgin - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|''[[The Glorification of the Virgin]]'' ({{circa}} 1490–1495) by [[Geertgen tot Sint Jans]]]]
The tradition of honoring Mary by venerating images of her goes back to 3rd-century Christianity.<ref>''Catholic Customs and Traditions: A Popular Guide'' by Greg Dues 1993 {{ISBN|0-89622-515-1}} page 126 [https://books.google.com/books?id=ajZ_aR-VXn8C&pg=PA126&dq=catholic+venerate+image+mary&hl=en&ei=3VagTIrnDsqNjAf4nYjDBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> Following the period of [[iconoclasm]], the position of the Church with respect to the veneration of images was formalized at the [[Second Council of Nicaea]] in 787. A summary of the doctrine is included in the current ''Catechism of the Catholic Church''. <blockquote> The Christian veneration of images is not contrary to the first commandment which proscribes idols. Indeed, "the honour rendered to an image passes to its prototype," and "whoever venerates an image venerates the person portrayed in it." The honour paid to sacred images is a "respectful veneration," not the adoration due to God alone: Religious worship is not directed to images in themselves, considered as mere things, but under their distinctive aspect as images leading us on to God Incarnate. The movement toward the image does not terminate in it as image, but tends towards that whose image it is.<ref>{{CCC|2132}}</ref> </blockquote>
No other image (in either the [[Western Church|Western]] or the [[Eastern Church]]) permeates Christian art as much as the image of Madonna and Child.<ref>''The Celebration of Faith: The Virgin Mary'' by Alexander Schmemann 2001 {{ISBN|0-88141-141-8}} page 11 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Sls53hUSodgC&printsec=frontcover&dq=ISBN+0881411418&hl=en&ei=4j6jTOC3EIOA4QaZrLzbAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref> The images of the Virgin Mary have become central [[icon]]s of [[Roman Catholicism]] and [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Orthodox]] [[Christianity]] where Mary remains a central artistic topic.<ref>''Merriam-Webster's encyclopedia of world religions'' by Wendy Doniger, 1999 {{ISBN|0-87779-044-2}} page 696</ref> Byzantine images of the ''Theotokos'' were adopted in the West, where Byzantine models became widely distributed in by the 7th century. The Virgin Mary has been one of the major subjects of [[Christian Art]], [[Art in Roman Catholicism|Catholic Art]] and [[Western Art]] since [[Early Christian art]] and she has been very widely portrayed in iconic "portraits", often known as [[Madonna (art)|Madonnas]], with the infant Jesus in the ''[[Madonna and Child]]'', and in a number of narrative scenes from her life known as the ''[[Life of the Virgin]]'', as well as scenes illustrating particular doctrines or beliefs: from masters such as [[Michelangelo]], [[Raphael]], [[Bartolomé Esteban Murillo|Murillo]] and [[Botticelli]] to [[folk art]].<ref>''Grieving with Mary: Finding Comfort and Healing in Devotion to the Mother of God'' by Mary K. Doyle 2009 {{ISBN|0-87946-397-X}} page 42</ref><ref>''Mary in Western art'' by Timothy Verdon, Filippo Rossi 2005 {{ISBN|0-9712981-9-X}} page 11</ref>
Some Marian art subjects include:
* [[Annunciation]] * [[Adoration of the Magi in Art|Adoration of the Magi]] * [[Adoration of the shepherds]] * [[Assumption of the Virgin Mary in Art|The Assumption in Art]] * [[Coronation of the Virgin]] * [[Christ taking leave of his mother]] * [[Roman Catholic Marian art#Immaculate Conception|Immaculate Conception]] * [[Pietà]]
[[Roman Catholic Marian art|Marian art]] enjoys a significant level of diversity, e.g. with distinct styles of statues of the Virgin Mary present on different continents (as depicted in the galleries in [[Roman Catholic Marian art]]). These depictions are not restricted to European art, and also appear in South American paintings.<ref>''The Virgin, saints, and angels: South American paintings 1600–1825'' by Suzanne L. Stratton-Pruitt 2006 {{ISBN|88-7624-613-4}} pages 34</ref> The South American tradition of Marian veneration through art dates back to the 16th century, with the [[Virgin of Copacabana]] gaining fame in 1582.<ref>Donahue-Wallace, Kelly (2008). ''Art and Architecture of Viceregal Latin America, 1521–1821''. Diálogos (Albuquerque, N.M.). Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press. p. 143. {{ISBN|978-0-8263-3459-6}}</ref>
==Marian movements and societies== {{Main|Roman Catholic Marian Movements and Societies}} <!--

--> Throughout the centuries the devotion to and the veneration of the Virgin Mary by Roman Catholics has both led to, and been influenced by a number of [[Roman Catholic Marian Movements and Societies]]. These societies form part of the fabric of [[Roman Catholic Mariology]].<ref name="udayton1" /><ref>''Early modern confraternities in Europe and the Americas'' by Christopher F. Black, Pamela Gravestock 2006 {{ISBN|0-7546-5174-6}} page 11</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/14120a.htm | title = Catholic encyclopedia | publisher = Newadvent.org | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref> As early as the 16th century, the [[Holy See]] endorsed the [[Sodality of Our Lady]] and [[Pope Gregory XIII]] issued a [[Papal Bull]] commending it and granting it [[indulgences]] and establishing it as the ''mother sodality'', and other sodalities were formed thereafter.<ref>''The Sodality of Our Lady: historical sketches'' by P.J. Kenedy & sons, 1916 ISBN page 37</ref><ref>''History of the sodalities of the blessed virgin Mary'' by Louis Delplace 1884 {{ISBN|1-141-60228-8}} page 211</ref><ref>''Maiden and Mother: Prayers, Hymns, Devotions, and Songs to the Beloved Virgin Mary Throughout the Year by Margaret M. Miles 2001 {{ISBN|0-86012-305-7}} page 125</ref>
The 18th and 19th centuries saw a number of missionary Marian organizations such as [[Company of Mary]], the [[Marianists]], the [[Marist Fathers]], and the [[Marist Brothers]]. Some of these missionaries, e.g. Saint [[Peter Chanel]], were martyred as they travelled to new lands.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11769a.htm | title = Catholic encyclopedia | publisher = Newadvent.org | date = February 1, 1911 | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/09749d.htm | title = Catholic encyclopedia | publisher = Newadvent.org | date = October 1, 1910 | accessdate = November 20, 2010}}</ref> The 20th century witnessed the formation of Marian organizations with millions of members, e.g. the [[Legion of Mary]] and [[Blue Army of Our Lady of Fatima]].<ref>Joan Carroll Cruz, ''Saintly Men of Modern Times'' (2003) {{ISBN|1-931709-77-7}} pages 117–118</ref><ref>Thomas McGonigle, 1996, ''A History of the Christian Tradition'' Paulist Press {{ISBN|978-0-8091-3648-3}} page 222</ref><ref>''A pilgrim's handbook to Fatima'' by Leo Madigan 2001 {{ISBN|0-85244-532-6}} page 207</ref><ref>''Catholic Dictionary'' by Peter M. J. Stravinskas 2002 {{ISBN|0-87973-390-X}} page 141</ref>

The local [[Ordinary (officer)|ordinary]] must approve the shrine.<ref>''New commentary on the Code of Canon Law'' by John P. Beal, James A. Coriden, Thomas J. Green 2002 {{ISBN|0-8091-4066-7}} page 1437 (Canon 1230)</ref>
Marian shrines account for major veneration centers and pilgrimage sites for Roman Catholics. According to Bishop Francesco Giogia, at the end of the 20th century, the most visited Catholic shrine in the world was that of the [[Virgin of Guadalupe]] in Mexico City. In third place was [[Basilica of the National Shrine of Our Lady of Aparecida|Our Lady of Aparecida]] in Brazil, with the non-Marian shrine of [[San Giovanni Rotondo]] in second place.<ref name="autogenerated1" /> The visual effect of Marian pilgrimages can be dramatic, e.g. on May 13 and October 13 of each year close to one million Catholic pilgrims walk the country road that leads to the [[Sanctuary of Our Lady of Fátima]].<ref>Trudy Ring, 1996, ''International Dictionary of Historic Places'', {{ISBN|978-1-884964-02-2}} page 245</ref> Around 2 million pilgrim journey up [[Tepeyac hill]] on December 12 each year to visit the [[Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe]].<ref>''Pilgrimage: from the Ganges to Graceland : an encyclopedia, Volume 1'' by Linda Kay Davidson, David Martin Gitlitz 2002 {{ISBN|1-57607-004-2}} page 213</ref> While in 1968 Aparecida had about four million pilgrims,<ref>''Brazil rediscovered'' by Roberta C. Wigder 1977 {{ISBN|0-8059-2328-4}} page 235</ref> the number has since reached eight million pilgrims per year.<ref>''Pilgrimage: from the Ganges to Graceland : an encyclopedia, Volume 1'' by Linda Kay Davidson, David Martin Gitlitz 2002 {{ISBN|1-57607-004-2}} page 38</ref>
